overview.title: Overview
overview.description: The JDK Management Tool supports integration with mainstream IDEs, including IntelliJ IDEA, Eclipse, VS Code, etc. By configuring the JDK path in your IDE, you can use the JDK versions managed by our tool.

benefits.title: Integration Benefits
benefits.description:
1. Unified Management: All IDEs use the same JDK version management tool
2. Quick Switching: Switch JDK versions anytime, IDEs will automatically detect changes
3. Multi-version Support: Configure different JDK versions for different projects
4. Environment Consistency: Ensure development and build environments use the same JDK version

config.title: IDE Configuration Guide
config.description:
### IntelliJ IDEA Configuration
1. Open Settings (Ctrl+Alt+S)
2. Go to Build, Execution, Deployment > Build Tools
3. Configure Gradle JVM or Maven JVM to use the symlink path

### VS Code Configuration
Add to settings.json:
```json
{
    "java.jdt.ls.java.home": "C:\Users\YourUsername\AppData\Local\Programs\jvman\current",
    "java.configuration.runtimes": [
        {
            "name": "JavaSE-Current",
            "path": "C:\Users\YourUsername\AppData\Local\Programs\jvman\current",
            "default": true
        }
    ]
}
```

### Eclipse Configuration
1. Window > Preferences
2. Java > Installed JREs
3. Add JRE, select the symlink path

### Build Tool Configuration

#### Gradle Configuration
In build.gradle:
```groovy
compileJava {
    sourceCompatibility = '17'
    targetCompatibility = '17'
    options.encoding = 'UTF-8'
}
```

#### Maven Configuration
In pom.xml:
```xml
<project>
    <properties>
        <maven.compiler.source>17</maven.compiler.source>
        <maven.compiler.target>17</maven.compiler.target>
    </properties>
    
    <build>
        <plugins>
            <plugin>
                <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugins</groupId>
                <artifactId>maven-compiler-plugin</artifactId>
                <version>3.11.0</version>
                <configuration>
                    <release>17</release>
                </configuration>
            </plugin>
        </plugins>
    </build>
</project>
```

faq.title: Common Issues
faq.description:
### IDE Cannot Recognize JDK
1. Verify symlink path is correct
2. Restart IDE
3. Clear IDE cache

### Project Build Fails
1. Check project JDK version settings
2. Verify build tool configuration
3. Update project dependencies

### Environment Variable Issues
1. Verify JAVA_HOME is set correctly
2. Check if Path includes JDK bin directory
3. Restart terminal or IDE

overview.title: Overview
overview.description: The JDK Version Manager seamlessly integrates with mainstream IDEs, enabling synchronization between development and runtime environments. By configuring IDEs to use the symlink path, your IDE's JDK environment will automatically sync when switching system JDK versions.

usage.title: Usage Recommendations
usage.description:
Project Configuration

Use relative paths to reference JDK in build configuration files (e.g., build.gradle or pom.xml):
// Gradle example
java {
    toolchain {
        languageVersion = JavaLanguageVersion.of(17) // Specify Java version
    }
}

Team Collaboration

  • Standardize JDK Version Manager usage across the team
  • Document symlink path configuration in project documentation
  • Include IDE JDK configuration files in version control (e.g., Git)

CI/CD Configuration

  • Use the same symlink path in CI/CD environments
  • Ensure JDK Version Manager is installed on build servers

faq.title: Common Issues
faq.description:
Symlink Path Not Found

  • Verify JDK Version Manager installation
  • Check if a JDK version is selected and activated

IDE Cannot Recognize JDK

  • Verify symlink functionality
  • Try restarting the IDE
  • Clear IDE cache and reconfigure

IDE Not Updating After Version Switch

  • Some IDEs may require project reload or restart
  • Check IDE auto-refresh settings

intellij.title: IntelliJ IDEA Configuration
steps: File â†’ Project Structure â†’ SDKs â†’ Add JDK â†’ Select symlink path

eclipse.title: Eclipse Configuration
steps: Window â†’ Preferences â†’ Java â†’ Installed JREs â†’ Add â†’ Select JDK â†’ Select symlink path

benefits.title: Benefits
env_points: Symlink path remains constant, IDE configuration only needed once
No IDE configuration changes needed when switching JDK versions
Avoid repeated JDK path modifications across projects
project_points: Different projects can use different JDK versions
Project configuration files can use the same JDK path
Unified configuration among team members, avoiding version conflicts
version_points: Switch JDK versions anytime, IDE automatically recognizes changes
Support for project-level and global version management
Easy testing of different JDK version compatibility

practices.title: Best Practices
path_points: Use absolute paths for symlinks to avoid relative path issues
Avoid using non-ASCII characters in symlink paths
Recommend placing symlink path in a stable location outside system drive
version_points: Document required JDK versions in project documentation
Recommend team-wide use of this tool for JDK management
performance_points: Regularly clear IDE cache, especially after version switches
Restart IDE to ensure new version configurations take effect
